HMPV Case LIVE: Fresh case reported from Gujarat, Himachal issues directive; India saw over 200 infections till December | Today News - Mint
summary:
HMPV Case LIVE: India saw over 200 infections till December; what WHO said about the virus?

Date: 10 Jan 2025
Source: LiveMint

The article discusses the rising concern around respiratory infections in India, particularly related to the Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV), with various state governments raising surveillance and issuing guidelines. As of January 2025, over 200 cases have been logged since the previous year.

  • Over 200 HMPV cases reported in India from January to December.
  • Nine new cases confirmed in early January 2025, including an 80-year-old man in Ahmedabad.
  • HMPV has been in circulation since 2001 and is not considered a new threat, according to health officials.
  • WHO stated that the increase in cases is expected and not unusual for this time of year.
  • Public is encouraged to follow preventive measures similar to those for other respiratory illnesses.
“HMPV is a common respiratory virus found to circulate in many countries in winter through to spring.” - WHO

In conclusion, the WHO and local health officials emphasize that while HMPV cases are rising, the virus is not new, and there is no cause for alarm, but public vigilance and hygiene practices are recommended.
newTitle: Over 200 HMPV Infections Reported in India; WHO Updates on Virus

Cluster of new mpox variant found in China: Know what it is - India Today
summary:
Cluster of New Mpox Variant Found in China: Know What It Is

Publication Date: Jan 10, 2025 | Source: India Today

Chinese health officials have identified a new mutated strain of mpox, known as clade Ib, in a foreigner who had traveled to the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). This finding comes as mpox continues to spread globally, prompting concern from health authorities.

  • A cluster of cases was linked to an individual from the DRC, with four additional cases reported among close contacts.
  • Symptoms among infected individuals are reported to be mild, including skin rashes and blisters.
  • Mpox transmits through close contact and can lead to serious health issues in vulnerable populations.
  • Infection rates and deaths in the DRC raise alarms, particularly concerning individuals with underlying health conditions.
  • WHO's designation of mpox as a global public health emergency highlights the need for monitoring and containment measures.
"Clade Ib seems to be different, and is spreading largely through contact between humans, including through sex. Around 18,000 suspected cases of mpox, many of them among children, and at least 600 deaths potentially attributable to the disease have been reported this year (2024) in the DRC alone."

The mpox situation underscores the importance of public awareness and health measures to control the spread of this viral disease.
newTitle: Cluster of New Mpox Variant Identified in China

Malaika Arora Feels 'Energised With The Winter Sun': 6 Health Benefits Of Sunbathing - TheHealthSite
summary:
Malaika Arora Feels 'Energised With The Winter Sun': 6 Health Benefits Of Sunbathing

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Health Site

Malaika Arora emphasizes the importance of moderate sun exposure during winter, sharing how it can be beneficial for health. She believes that basking in sunlight not only energizes but also promotes overall well-being.

  • Boosts vitamin D levels, essential for bone health.
  • Reduces seasonal affective disorder (SAD) and improves mood.
  • Supports circadian rhythm, enhancing sleep quality and energy levels.
  • Improves skin health by promoting collagen production.
  • Increases energy and alertness, combating fatigue.
  • Supports immune function, aiding in fighting infections.
"Energised with the winter sun," - Malaika Arora

In conclusion, embracing the winter sun can have various health benefits, making it a valuable practice for enhancing physical and mental well-being.

title: First HMPV case in elderly reported in India amid China's recent surge - Business Standard
summary:
First HMPV Case in Elderly Reported in India Amid China's Recent Surge

Publication Date: Recent Report, Source: Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation

This article discusses the first reported case of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) in an elderly man in India, following a recent outbreak in China. The patient is currently in stable condition and receiving treatment.

  • An 80-year-old man detected with HMPV infection in Ahmedabad.
  • First instance of elderly infection since the outbreak in China.
  • The patient has no travel history abroad.
  • Condition is stable; he has a history of asthma.
  • HMPV typically causes mild respiratory symptoms; most recover without treatment.
  • Monitoring and preventive measures are in place by the central government.
The virus infection is usually mild and self-limiting and most people recover on their own.

The detection of HMPV in this elderly patient underscores the importance of continued surveillance and awareness regarding respiratory infections.
newTitle: First HMPV Case in Elderly Reported in India Amid China's Recent Surge

THESE work habits are putting your sleep at risk, says study - The Times of India
summary:
THESE work habits are putting your sleep at risk, says study

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Times of India

A study by the University of South Florida reveals that sedentary jobs and non-traditional work hours significantly contribute to insomnia symptoms, impacting over 10,000 employees' sleep health.

  • 80% of the modern workforce is highly sedentary.
  • Those with sedentary jobs have a 37% greater likelihood of insomnia symptoms.
  • Individuals working non-traditional hours have a 66% increased risk of needing catch-up sleep.
  • 90% of insomnia-like sleepers experience persistent symptoms a decade later.
“The way we are designing work poses serious, long-term threats to healthy sleep.” - Claire Smith

This research emphasizes the need for companies to redesign jobs to improve sleep health and overall employee productivity.
newTitle: Study Highlights Work Habits Impacting Sleep Quality

title: Groundbreaking G6PD diagnostic test prequalified by WHO to ensure safe malaria treatment - News-Medical.Net
summary:
Groundbreaking G6PD diagnostic test prequalified by WHO to ensure safe malaria treatment

Date: 18 December 2024 | Source: WHO

The World Health Organization has prequalified the first diagnostic test for G6PD deficiency, enhancing safe treatment options for malaria caused by P. vivax.

  • Significant milestone for malaria treatment, particularly P. vivax.
  • 500,000 malaria-related deaths each year, predominantly among children.
  • This test complements recent approvals of tafenoquine products for anti-relapse treatment.
  • Streamlined processes by WHO aim to expedite access to vital health products.
  • G6PD deficiency affects over 500 million people, complicating treatment options.

"Wider availability of the test can help strengthen the global malaria response by reducing the number of P. vivax infections due to relapse and in turn reduce onward transmission." - Dr. Daniel Ngamije Madandi, WHO

The STANDARD G6PD System is designed to facilitate quick and reliable testing in varied settings, ensuring appropriate treatment for patients.
newTitle: WHO Prequalifies Groundbreaking G6PD Diagnostic Test for Safe Malaria Treatment

title: Innovative cure for dengue and malaria: 'Toxic' semen from male mosquitoes kills females - The Times of India
summary:
Innovative Cure for Dengue and Malaria: 'Toxic' Semen from Male Mosquitoes Kills Females

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Time of India

An innovative approach to combat dengue and malaria is making waves as researchers discover that 'toxic' semen from male mosquitoes could effectively kill female mosquitoes, potentially controlling the spread of these diseases.

  • The research highlights the use of male mosquitoes in disease control strategies.
  • Female mosquitoes, which are responsible for biting and spreading disease, are targeted.
  • This method offers a novel biological solution to a long-standing public health issue.
"This breakthrough could revolutionize our approach to combating mosquito-borne diseases," says lead researcher.

This innovative strategy could provide a sustainable and effective method for reducing the populations of disease-carrying mosquitoes, ultimately aiming for better health outcomes in affected regions.
newTitle: Innovative Cure for Dengue and Malaria: 'Toxic' Semen from Male Mosquitoes Kills Females

Can Ozempic damage your optic nerve? Here’s what doctors say about a new study - The Indian Express
summary:
Can Ozempic damage your optic nerve? Here’s what doctors say about a new study

Date: January 9, 2025 | Source: Indian Express

A recent Danish study indicates that semaglutide, a medication used for controlling blood glucose and aiding in weight loss, may be linked to an increased risk of vision loss related to damage of the optic nerve. However, Indian doctors emphasize that evidence is not yet conclusive regarding this risk.

  • A Danish study shows that semaglutide usage may lead to higher risks for non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION).
  • The study observed 67 cases of NAION in individuals exposed to semaglutide over a period of up to 23 months.
  • The incidence of NAION was noted to be 0.228 per 1000 person-years among diabetics using semaglutide.
  • Benefits of semaglutide include effective blood glucose control, weight loss, and heart health improvements.
  • Doctors in India are cautious, discussing the potential indirect impacts on the nervous system, yet assert that no direct evidence of optic nerve damage exists locally.
“Any study must be weighed against the absolute benefits of GLP-1 molecules, which outweigh the risks, at least in this case.” - Dr. VN Shah

In summary, while there are concerns about potential vision loss associated with semaglutide, medical professionals stress the importance of considering its overall benefits.
newTitle: Can Ozempic Damage Your Optic Nerve? Doctors Weigh In on New Study

HMPV cases in India: Understanding its lesser-known impact on eye health - Hindustan Times
summary:
HMPV cases in India: From pink eye to keratitis, know the HMPV-related eye conditions.

Date: Jan 09, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

HMPV, or Human Metapneumovirus, causes cold-like symptoms and has recently been detected in India, raising concerns about its impact on eye health.

  • HMPV leads to symptoms like cough, fever, and nasal congestion.
  • It can result in eye-related complications such as conjunctivitis and keratitis.
  • Individuals with compromised immune systems are at higher risk.
  • Early detection is crucial for managing eye complications.
“While primarily associated with respiratory symptoms, HMPV has been linked to eye-related complications in some cases,” said Dr. Karthikeya R.

Monitoring HMPV's effects on eye health can prevent long-term vision issues. Awareness and preventive measures are essential to manage its spread.
newTitle: HMPV Cases in India: Impact on Eye Health
